With the help of her past 16 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marilyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 19,500 Philippine pesos helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 17th loan, she is borrowing PHP 21,000, which she intends to use as revolving working capital for her food-vending business so that she can continue to save up for the future security of her family and for the education of her child who is still going to school. Marilyn A. is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable") way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: Additional working capital for business

loans.name: Maria Helen

texts.es: La señora  María  estado civil casada tiene cuatro hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar ella y su familia vive en la casa de los  padres de la Sra. María  que esta ubicado en el  Barrio el Carmen  Busch entre  tercer anillo externo. La Sra. María se dedica la venta de cosméticos hace  seis años nos comenta que su gran deseo es de tener una tienda grande  para vender sus productos .El crédito que se le otorgo a la clienta  es para la compra de sus productos de cosméticos al contado. La Sra. María manifestó que esta muy agradecida con nuestra institución por la confianza brindada en la otorgación del crédito.
texts.en:
María is married and has four school age children.  She and her family live her in parents’ house, which is located in the Carmen Busch neighborhood amid Tercer Anillo Externo.

María has been selling cosmetics for six years. She tells us that her big wish is to have a large store in which to sell her products.

The loan is to buy her cosmetic products for cash.  María is very grateful to our institution and for the trust show in granting the loan.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics in bulk

loans.name: Euphemia

texts.en:
Euphemia is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is rent.

She has operated her retail shop business for over three years, selling to her neighbors and passersby. Euphemia faces the challenge of theft because of insecurity in the area. She hopes to purchase a piece of land to construct rental houses in the future. 

With the 40,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of sugar, rice, maize flour and bundles of wheat flour.
She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of sugar, rice, maize flour and bundles of wheat flour.

loans.name: Tamemsu Traders Group

texts.en:
Aminata K. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Born in Kambia town, in northern Sierra Leone, Aminata is married and has five children who are attending secondary school.  For thirty years now, Aminata has been selling cooked food. She will use her share of the loan (SLL 600,000) to expand her business. She will buy palm oil (the country’s favorite cooking oil), rice, onions, and other cooking ingredients in large quantity. In this way, Aminata will no longer be buying these items retail, thereby saving her a lot of cash. 

This is not the first loan that Aminata and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of their previous loan, they were able to expand their businesses, made more sales and consequently improved their living conditions.

loans.use: Buy palm oil, rice, onions, and other cooking ingredients in large quantity

loans.name: Rani's Group

texts.en:
Rani lives in Borewala, which is a small city in the Punjab Province of Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has lived there in Akhter town with her family in a 2-room brick house for over many years. 

She is a house wife, and prefers to stay at home and do her household work. She has given birth to 2 sons and a daughter. She couldn’t provide them educational facilities due to financial constraints. Her elder son started driving a rickshaw on rent, while the other son stays at home and doesn't do anything.   Her daughter is only 6 years old, and Rani has plan to enroll her in school in the near future. 

Her husband is also a driver by trade. He runs a rickshaw to provide transport services to his customers. He adopted this profession 3 years ago and people know him as a good driver. 

Rani has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband, who wants to repair his rickshaw because its engine is having problems and doesn’t work properly.  The loan amount will help him repair his rickshaw fully.   Rani is hopeful that this investment will help her husband keep his vehicle in better condition, and help him improve his services for his clients. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and has maintained a good credit record in every loan year. This is the fifth time she has applied for a loan. 

Note: In the photo, the lady who holds a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Rani.

loans.use: To repair a rickshaw

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy merchandise wholesale

loans.name: 02-  Mật Sơn 2- Đông Vệ Group

texts.en:
Thanh C. Thị (04) is a 57-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá. Thanh is the leader of a seven-member group loan offered by Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 02- Mật Sơn 2- Đông Vệ (08.09.02 Đông Vệ ).
Thanh is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Thanh owns and operates a business manufacturing and selling to local businesses and community members.  Thanh has been engaged in this business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND per month from these activities.
In 2010, Thanh joined Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thanh is requesting her first loan from Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women. She is requesting a loan of 4,248,000 VND, which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Thanh plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group
1.  N. Thị Thơ (05) is a 48-year-old female who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her manufacturing business.
2.  L. Thị Huệ (06) is a 59-year-old female who is requesting a 4,248,000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a manufacturing business.
3.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase sheep

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a 25 year old single young man who is very ambitious and hardworking. He lives in a place called Waithaka, which is on the outskirts of Nairobi town. Most of the residents here are farmers both crop and animal farmers. Paul is practicing animal farming by rearing Dairy cattle and selling the milk to the locals. 

This will be Paul’s first loan with KADET LTD and he intends to use it to venture in poultry farming in addition to the dairy farming that he is currently in.

In future, Paul hopes to own a big farm and be able to supply farm products in Waithaka and Kikuyu town.

loans.use: Paul plans to start poultry farming

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
We do not need to make a lot of mistakes before we get to learn. At the age of 54, Evelyn learns the ways of both business and life to get going at a better pace. She finished her high school education but her training in CCT* as a Community Partner enables her to run a business with confidence. She is married to Rodolfo T., a foreman. They live in Malaria, Caloocan City along with their two children, who are in high school.

Evelyn has been in the direct selling business for three years and is still doing her best to master her trade. She tries to figure out what her customers like when it comes to bags, shoes, shirts and pants. With no employees to help her sell, Evelyn gives her utmost strength to make her business work. She earns an estimated income of 8,000 PHP per month.

To help her grow her business, Evelyn is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy quality apparel to make sure that her customers get only the best in the market, as well as purchase those items ordered in advance by her customers. With this money on hand, she can easily improve her business, one lesson she learned in her fellowship* with fellow community partners.

Just like any micro entrepreneur, Evelyn also suffers from customers who do not pay their debts. Still, as she learns how to be a successful entrepreneur, she also learns how to deal with such difficult times in business. The simplest dreams she has in her heart is for her family to have good health and to see her children graduate from college.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase inventory and stocks ordered in advance by customers.

loans.name: Moses Njogu

texts.en:
Moses has been selling milk in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last seven years.  He is 35 years old, married to Esther Muthoni, and they have four children.

Moses was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his fourth loan. He repaid all his previous loans well and in good time.  He plans to use this loan amount to buy a new motorbike for use in his milk distribution business.

In the future, Moses hopes to grow his milk sale business and be a leading supplier of milk in Ndunyu Njeru town.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for use in milk distribution

loans.name: Mrs. Kuch Tin Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of fifteen people from Prey Phdau Cheung village, Takeo province. They will use their portion of the loan in different ways to improve their families' living conditions. They have selected Mrs. Kuch T. as the village bank president. Mrs. Kuch T. was born in 1979 and is a weaver who makes money by selling silk cloth to support her family. Since her business is getting on well, she wants to expand. To improve her business, Mrs. Kuch T. is seeking a loan to buy more silk for weaving. Her husband, Mr. Chea Em, is a construction worker and a farmer who owns a half-hectare plot of land where he grows rice for sale to support his family. This couple supports two children: one is a student, while the other is only seven months old.

loans.use: To buy more silk for weaving

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba A. has a small wooden stand on the roadside in the town of Jukwa which is near Abura close to Cape Coast. She sells fried fish and smoked fish of different kinds. Several times a week she prepares the fish at her place. 

Aba is hoping for a loan because she would like to buy more fresh fish in order to be able to prepare more fish so she can then sell to her customers. Aba is married to an electrical repairman and she assists him in taking care of the family needs. With the new profits of her expanded business, she hopes to be able to save some money for their children’s education which is very important to her and her husband.

loans.use: to buy more fresh fish to fry or smoke for sale.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma C. is from the village of Begonia, Suarez, Iligan City. She is 39 years old, married and has 9 school-aged children. Vilma owns and operates a business making and selling snacks and other delicacies such as rice and cheesecakes in the local community. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Vilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Vilma is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients such as flour and eggs. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Vilma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients

loans.name: Apec-Al Ouma Mekhe Groupe 2

texts.fr:
Apec-Al Ouma Mekhe groupe 2 est un démembrement de la cellule de Mekhe qui est affiliée a l’association Al Ouma. Il est composé de 26 membres (hommes et femmes) qui habitent la même localité et s’activent dans le secteur de l’agriculture et de l’élevage depuis leur enfance. Ils ont la particularité d’être tous issus de familles d’agriculteurs et d’éleveur ce qui explique en partie leur amour vis-à-vis de l’activité qu’ils exercent. Mais d’autre part ils sont plutôt intéressés par la réalisation de bénéfices que leur procurent leurs activités respectives. Le groupe 2 de Apec Al Ouma Mekhe est représenté par monsieur Cheikh D. qui élève un troupeau au village mais parallèlement acquiert des futs d’huile qu’il place auprès des boutiquiers de Yoff. Il pratique cette activité rentable depuis plus de 5 ans. Ils sollicitent un crédit de 2 250 000 frs prévu pour l’achat  de bétail, de semence et de pesticide. Le but recherché par les différents bénéficiaires est le développement de leurs activités qui pourra participer positivement à l’amélioration du cadre de vie de leurs familles et au développement socio-économique du groupement.
Al Ouma is a Senegalese nonprofit whose full name is The Association for Koranic Education and Teaching. 
 
Originally founded to work with at-risk children, especially talibés (young boys from poor families who beg in Senegalese metropolitan areas), Al Ouma has evolved its mission to work with adults as well as children. They currently have over 10,000 members, and are actively engaged in supporting the economic development of their members in the hopes of improving their quality of life, and that of their at-risk children.
 
Al Ouma's members are currently organized into smaller associations which meet each week to contribute to a group fund that helps finance small loans for members.  Members typically put in $2 USD per week. Because UIMCEC and Al Ouma both share the mission of fighting poverty through economic empowerment, they have formed a partnership to provide loans to Al Ouma associations at a lower interest rate than UIMCEC usually offers its clients
texts.en: The Apec-Al Ouma Mekhe group 2 is part of the Mekhe branch affiliated to Al OUma. It is composed of 26 members (men and women) who live in the same village and work in agriculture and livestock farming since childhood. What is special about them is that all of them grew up in farmers’ famileos, which explains in part their attraction to this type of work. On the other hand, they are motivated by the income that this work brings. The group 2 of Apeck Al Ouma Mekhe is represented by Mr. Cheikh D., who raises a herd in the village and, as a parallel activity, buys barrels of vegetable oil that he resells to the stores in Yoff. He has been in this business for over 5 years. The group is seeking a loan of 2,250,000 West African francs for purchasing livestock, seeds and pesticides. Their goal is growing their business and improving the quality of life and socioeconomic status of their families.

loans.use: to buy livestock, seeds and pesticide

loans.name: Susuana

texts.en: Susuana K. is 20 years old and single. She is currently in business selling fruits and vegetables. She plans to use her loan to stock more fruits and vegetables. Her future goal is to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: to stock more fruit and vegetables.

loans.name: Ishdorj

texts.en:
Mr. Ishdorj is 30 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Ishdorj runs a taxi business using his family car. His wife looks after the baby at the moment.

 Ishdorj also runs a small farm with around 20 animals. His six cows are expected to give  birth soon. Ishdorj milks the cows with his wife's help and sells fresh milk and dairy products to his neighbors. Ishdorj is very hard-working and enthusiastic person. Last year he dug a well for water on his land and planted vegetables. He was overwhelmed with the harvest and it gave him a big inspiration. Now he is planning to buy a 84 sq. meter greenhouse which consists of a metal frame and polyethylene film and grow vegetables such as tomatoes, cucumbers, lettuces and so on. 

Ishdorj's family is very happy that now they will be able to use their own dairy products and vegetables all year around. The loan Mr.Ishdorj is requesting will be used to buy a greenhouse and vegetable seeds to grow vegetables for his family use.

loans.use: To buy a greenhouse and vegetable seeds and grow vegetables for family use.

loans.name: Jose Martin

texts.es:
José, vive con su esposa y tienen cuatro hijos de 11, 6, 5 años de edad, y el último de 4 meses de edad.
Él se dedica a la ganadería, trabaja desde hace 25 años en un horario de 4:00am a 4:00pm, esta actividad le ha permitido hasta el momento, brindar a su familia todo lo necesario en alimentación; actualmente solicita un préstamo para comprar ganado y otra parte para comprar insumos agrícolas como abono y fertilizantes.
Su objetivo es aumentar su capacidad de producción y en la ganadería, ya que desea continuar trabajando por mejorar cada vez más las condiciones de su familia y el futuro de sus hijos.
texts.en:
José lives with his wife and four children who are 11, 6 and 5 years of age; the youngest is four months old.

He raises livestock.  He has worked a 4am-4pm schedule for the last 25 years.  This work has, up to now, made it possible for him to provide his family with sustenance.  He currently needs a loan to buy cattle and to buy farming supplies, like manure and fertilizer.

His goal is to increase his productive capacity and his herd size because he wants to continue working to improve his family’s living conditions and his children’s future.

loans.use: to buy cattle and to buy farming supplies like manure and fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Torkunbubu's Group

texts.en:
Torkunbubu is the leader of this group. She is 49, married to a driver, and has four children. The older son is a farmer, the second son studies at university, and the other children attend school. The family breeds livestock to earn money. This year in order to earn additional money to meet their daily needs Torkunbubu started to sell Kyrgyz national drink, “Kumys” (horse milk). She is requesting a loan because she needs additional funds for expanding the business. Part of the loan will be used to purchase more “Kumys” and the other part will be used to purchase livestock for breeding. In the future, Torkunbubu wishes to purchase a big house in the village.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly), and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock

loans.name: Mussarat's Group

texts.en:
Mussarat is a caring lady. She keeps herself busy doing household work. She prefers staying at home and taking care of her family. 

Her husband has a food stall where he sells Punjabi food items called samosas (made with flour filled with potatoes and served with sweet & chilly sauces) and also pakodas (made with gram flour and also served with tomato and chilly sauces). 

These are the most demanded food items among his customers. He has been doing this work for many years. In his working experience, he has got a good reputation and earns well. 

Mussarat has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy gram flour, potatoes, spices, flour and cooking oil, etc. for expanding his food stall by providing good and quality food items to his customers. 

Mussarat is hopeful that her husband's business will expand further after the loan investment and her family will be able to enjoy a better standard of living as a result. 

Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Mussarat.

loans.use: To buy required ingredients for food stall business.

loans.name: Arnolfo

texts.en:
Arnolfo is 42 years old and married to Agnes. He is thankful because he is blessed with 2 children. They are generally school-aged.

Arnolfo grows rice and has been doing it for 18 years. He is grateful because through his patience in maintaining his rice farm he is able to earn PHP 60,000 (~$1410) per cropping. Due to the high cost of basic commodities and expensive farm supplies, he is in need of additional capital. In this regard, he is requesting a loan of PHP 50,000 which will be used to buy fertilizer and insecticides for his farm.

In the future, Arnolfo hopes to avail loan requests to further improve his farm and also to increase his profit.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticides for his farm.

loans.name: Gricelda

texts.es:
Griselda, vive con su familia, su esposo y una hija de 15 años de edad, ella tiene un año dedicándose al negocio de accesorios  y ha logrado sobrevivir de los ingresos que le provee.
Por el momento necesita comprar mercadería para surtir el negocio, pues necesita pulseras, poster animados, calcomanías, accesorios para el cabello y más productos que son del gusto de los jóvenes, pues su mercado principal son precisamente la juventud y los niños.
Su objetivo con el negocio es tener lo necesario para atender la demanda, esperando contar con clientela que le consuma y le genere ganancias.
texts.en:
Griselda lives with her family, her husband and 15 year old daughter.  She has been running an accessory business for a year now and has been able to survive on the income it provides.   At the moment she needs to buy merchandise to stock her business.  She needs bracelets, animated posters, stickers, hair accessories and more products that young people like as her main customers are young people and children.  

He business goal is to have what she needs to meet the demand.  She hopes to have customers that will buy and generate income.

loans.use: purchase bracelets, animated posters, stickers, hair accessories and more.

loans.name: Nassim

texts.en:
Nassim runs a natural juice making business, selling to her neighbors and passers-by. She has been engaged in her business for the past year. She faces the major challenge of water rationing, which leads to an inadequate supply of water for her customers. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

Nassim and her husband have two children, both of whom attend school. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. The family's greatest monthly expense is school fees.

With the Kshs 30,000 loan, she wants to pay for water installation so that she can start another business of selling water. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to pay for water installation so that she can start another business of selling water

loans.name: Saidi

texts.en:
Saidi is 48 years old and married. His wife is a housewife, and they are blessed with seven children. Saidi is a mason in Kilifi; his business has been in operation for the last 27 years. He serves the residents of Vitengeni in Kilifi with stones. His business is doing well.

Saidi is a KADET client and this is his second loan to finance his business. With this loan he plans to expand his business by purchasing more tools and to also hire more people into his business. 

The anticipated profits will be used to repay the loan and for his upkeep. Saidi’s dream is to have a happy and successful life.

loans.use: to purchase more tools for his business

loans.name: Telman

texts.en: Telman is 45 and lives with his wife and children in their own house in Agsu. Telman started his beekeeping business in 1998, and it's improving a lot. He sells his product, honey, in the local market. When he first received a loan from AqroInvest in 2010, he made a good profit and the loan was useful to him.  He has applied to AqroInvest and Kiva for his second loan of 1500 AZN to buy modern supplies. Telman dreams of seeing his production grow, to generate more profits and to be able to provide his family with a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy modern supplies for beekeeping.

loans.name: Harriet's Group

texts.en:
Harriet's group is comprised of three hard-working women. Harriet is 19 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda. For the past six months, Harriet has been working hard to manage her small catering business, where she sells fruits and delivers hot meals to local families and businesses. 

To help expand her business, Harriet has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more supplies and will help Harriet to generate greater profits and pay school fees. Harriet hopes that in the future she will be able to be a radio reporter. 

Harriet is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life skills training. The ELA program has increased Harriet's future prospects by helping her to pay her school fees and learn more about running a business.

loans.use: to purchase more supplies,

loans.name: Bineta

texts.fr: Bineta est une célibataire de 27 ans  qui vit dans une des localités de la banlieue du Sénégal. Elle est mère d’un enfant de 5 ans.  Elle  exerce l ‘activité de femme de ménage depuis 2001 dans l’un des guichets de l’U-IMCEC ou elle est membre. Parallèlement  elle évolue dans le commerce depuis 2008. La raison de son choix pour l’activité de commerce se justifie par le fait qu’elle éprouvait le besoin de combler ses besoins sociaux. Elle est sociétaire depuis juillet 2004 et a déjà remboursé 9 crédits antérieurs. Elle sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de bijoux et d’habits à vendre pour les préparatifs de la fête  de Tabaski. Ce financement lui permettra d’accroitre ses  revenus, de subvenir a ses besoins et surtout d’ aider ses parents dans la gestion des dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en: Bineta is a 27-year old single woman living in a suburb in Senegal. She is the mother of a five-year child. Since 2001, she has been working as a cleaning woman in the branch of U-IMCEC in which she is a member. In addition, since 2008 she has been  working as a vendor. Her reason for going into business is the need to improve her socioeconomic status. She has been a member since July 24 and already repaid nine prior loans. She is seeking a credit of 100,000 West African francs in order buy clothing and jewelry to resell ahead of  the Tabaski holiday [the Muslim holiday also known as  the Feast of Sacrifice]. This financing will allow her to increase her revenues, to support herself and, before all, to help her parents with their everyday expenses.

loans.use: to buy clothing and jewelry for resale

loans.name: Bakari

texts.en:
Bakari is a married man with ten school-going children. He has two wives that operate a small business and also contribute to the provision of the family's basic needs. He has a house with piped water but not electricity. His greatest monthly expenses are food for his family and school fees for his children. 

Bakari has operated as a large scale farmer for the past thirty years. His potential clients are his neighbors, friends and café owners. He faces a major challenge of irrigation, especially during the dry seasons when water is hard to find. He dreams of establishing a well operating farm ranch.

With the Kshs 40,000 he wants to purchase crop seedlings to plant and hire laborers to help him on his farm. He decided to join Yehu because it offers loan facilities to men.

loans.use: To purchase crop seedlings to plant and hire laborers to help him on his farm.

loans.name: Kunakuera Katupyry Group

texts.es:
Este grupo es D. la ciudad D. Encarnación, surgió por contacto D. una D. las señoras con la fundación, la cual motivo a sus amigas y vecinas para formar parte del programa D. fundación paraguaya. El grupo se encuentra en el tercer ciclo. Ellas día a día trabajan por lograr sus objetivos y D. esa forma poder cumplir con el desarrollo D. cada una.
Una D. las integrantes del grupo es la Sra. Eustacia, ella se dedica hace varios años a la venta D. sábanas y cortinas. Este trabajo y sacrificio que realiza es por darle a su familia todo lo mejor, ya que no quiere que ellos pasen privaciones como las que ella tuvo que pasar. 
Ella solicita el préstamo para la compra D. sabanas y cortinas, con lo cual podrá aumentar su variedad y ofrecerlo a sus clientes.
texts.en:
This group is from the city of Encarnación and was formed through a contact of one of its members with the foundation.  She encouraged her friends and neighbors to join the Paraguay Foundation program.  The group is in its third cycle.  Every day they work to reach their goals and try to develop individually.

One of the members of the group is Mrs. Eustacia who has been selling sheets and curtains for several years.  The work and sacrifice she carries out are in order to give her family the best she can, since she does not want them to go without the things she had to.

She is requesting a loan to buy sheets and curtains to increase the variety of her inventory and offer it to her customers.

loans.use: To buy sheets and curtains to sell.

loans.name: Erwina

texts.en: Erwina is a married woman with three children. Erwina is 36 years old and lives in the Philippines. Erwina owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products to earn a living and she's been in this business for eight years. Each month, she earns PHP 4,500 doing this type of business. She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase products to resell. Erwina has been a member of GDMPC for a year. In the future, Erwina wants to build a house and to finish her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase products to resell

location.town: Campo 5, Ramon Magsaysay, Zamboanga Del Sur

loans.name: Rogelia

texts.es: La señora Rogelia se dedica a la confección de prendas deportivas, es cliente antigua de la institución,  responsable ya que paga sus cuotas puntualmente a la institución, ella vive en casa de su suegra, tiene un hijo pequeño, la señora Rogelia se dedica a la confección de ropa deportiva para jóvenes y adultos, las cuales distribuye en la localidad de sacaba los días miércoles y viernes, debido a que ella es conocida por las vendedoras ya que la ropa deportiva que confecciona tienen mucha demanda, con el dinero del crédito la Sra. comprara tela por mayor para la confección de ropa deportiva, la Sra. Rogelia con el tiempo desea tener un taller mas grande y así ofrecer sus productos en la ciudad de Cochabamba y Oruro.
texts.en: Rogelia sews athletic wear.  She is a longstanding client of the institution.  She is responsible in that she makes her payments to the institution punctually.  She lives in her mother-in-law’s house.  She has a small son.  Rogelia manufactures athletic wear for young adults and adults that she distributes in Sacaba Wednesdays and Fridays because she’s well known by the sellers because the clothes she makes are in high demand.  Rogelia will use the money from the loan to buy fabric at wholesale to make athletic wear.  In time, she’d like to have a larger workshop to offer her products in the cities of Cochabamba and Oruro.

loans.use: to buy fabric.

loans.name: Raul Alfredo

texts.es: El señor Raúl, es habitante del municipio de Ticuantepe, junto a su esposa e hijos, los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones de vidas, los sueños de don Raúl es que Dios le de las fuerzas suficiente para poder apoyar a su hijos para que lleguen a ser profesionales, ya que él es de muy escasos recursos y tiene muchas limitante para poder darle a su familia una vida digna , con este financiamiento va a construir el baño de su vivienda ya que el actual es de plástico y no tiene piso , el va a comprar cemento , bloques , hierro , arena , piedrín , zinc y pintura .Agradece el apoyo que le brinda Afodenic atraves de fondo Kiva ya que le dan la confianza a personas pobres pero con muchas ganas de superarse.
texts.en: Señor Raúl lives in the municipality of Ticuantepe with his wife and children. The plans he has for his family are to improve their living conditions. Raul dreams that 'God will give him the strength' to support his children so they become professionals, as he is a man of little means and has many impediments to giving his family a decent life. With this loan he is going to build a bathroom for his house as the current one is made of plastic and has no floor. He is going to buy cement, cement blocks, iron, sand, gravel, zinc and paint. He is grateful to Afodenic for the support given him through Kiva as it gives poor people who are eager to succeed confidence.

loans.use: to buy building materials.

loans.name: Bunyod

texts.ru: Бунёд занимается в аграрном бизнесе более 7 лет. Он выращивает пшеницу и картофель. Еще он имеет комбайн, которым предоставляет услуги во время  сезона. В не сезонное время он занимается купле- продажей урожая. На полученную прибыль он хочет отремонтировать свой дом. Бунёд хочет расширить свой бизнес и получить хорошую прибыль. Он хотел бы получить займ в размере 12000 Сомони для покупки семян пшеницы и картофеля. Бунёд заранее благодарен вам за вашу доброту и помощь.
texts.en: Bunyod has been a farmer for the last seven years. He grows wheat and potatoes. He also owns a combine which he rents out during the harvesting season. During the slow growing times he sells and resells produce. He wants to use the the profits from the resale to repair his house. Bunyod would really like to expand his farm business and be able to earn higher profits. He is taking out this loan of 12000 somoni to purchase wheat seeds and seed potatoes for planting. Bunyod is grateful in advance for your kindness and assistance.

loans.use: To buy seeds of wheat and potatoes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy rice, ground nuts, etc. in bulk to add to her business

loans.name: Erika

texts.es:
Erika nació en la ciudad de Huayllabamba y vive en la misma ciudad donde nació. (El distrito peruano de Huayllabamba es uno de los siete distritos de la Provincia de Urubamba, ubicada en el Departamento del Cusco, perteneciente a la Región Cusco, Perú). 

Erika tiene 31 años edad y es casada y fruto de esta hermosa relación tiene un hijo, ella tiene dos actividad económicas principales que realiza durante todo el año. Ella trabaja como alfabetizadora del estado en el poblado de Urquillos de la provincia de Calca y también se dedica a la venta de choclo, pasto y otras verduras mas. En esta oportunidad Erika requiere el préstamo para comprar más verduras como choclo y pasto. 

Erika es integrante del banco comunal “Virgen Natividad” y el grupo está conformado con 15 socios que viven unos en la ciudad de Huayllabamba y otros en la ciudad de Yucay.
texts.en:
Erika was born in the city of Huayllabamba, and still lives in the city of her birth. (The peruvian district of Huayllabamba is one of the seven districts in the province of Urubamba, located in the Department and Region of Cusco.) 

Erika, age 31, has one child as a result of her happy marriage. She has two main areas of work all year round. She works as a state literacy teacher in the settlement of Urquillos in Calca province, and she also sells maize, hay and vegetables. Erika needs the loan to buy more vegetables. 

She is a member of the “Virgen Natividad” Communal Bank, a group formed of 15 members. some of the members live in the city of Huayllabamba and others in the city of Yucay.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables, maize and hay.

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
This is 43-year-old Mohamed.  He is married and has four children aged 10, 7, 4, and 2, all schooling. In 2001, Mohamed established his ladies' bags, necklaces, wallets, and cosmetics  business. He began his business because he wanted to avoid being idle and ensure that he is independent, and that is his only source of income. 

Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about Le 1,250,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000. Mohamed requires a loan in order to buy ladies' bags, men's chain wallets and bracelets. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 400,000.

 In the future, Mohamed plans to increase his capital, build a house, and educate his children.   He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy ladies' bags, men's chain wallets and bracelets.

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina, 61, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She and her husband have been involved in growing agricultural crops for over 10 years and are successful in their career. In order to improve her business, Sina is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase agricultural machinery to use in her business. In the future, she would like to run a rubber plantation and support her children to study until they get a Bachelor degree.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural machinery to use in her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve on farming methods and tools in order to raise the standard of living in the locality.

loans.name: Rada

texts.en: Rada is IDP from armenian occupied Jabrail region. As almost all IDPs she had many hardships and difficulties in sustaining the family. She rented a place in the market and started the business of selling women's clothing since 2001. In 2003 she applied to Normicro Beylagan branch and borrowed $300 to increase working capltal. Now she needs $1200 to increase the variety of clothing and volume of sales, thus increase income.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Vailaau

texts.en: Vailaau, 19, is married and has three children.  She wasn’t able to finish school and was unable to find a job.  She has attended some Women’s Committee seminars in her local village where local women teach other women how to sew, weave, design and make traditional Samoan crafts in order to allow a woman a means of supporting herself.  This is where Vailaau learned how to make the crafts that she now makes and is able to sell to bring in some income.  She has been using micro-loan facilities from SPBD in order to purchase raw materials for her crafts, which she re-sells at flea markets to locals and tourists.  Now having repaid in full four previous business loans, Vailaau is eligible for a home improvement and education loan.  She will use this loan to repair the damaged roof of her house, and to pay for her children’s school fees and uniforms.  Vailaau is confident that she can repay this loan (as she has all others) with the income from her crafts business.

loans.use: Home improvement and education fees

loans.name: Thelma Elizabeth

texts.es:
I run a small business from my home selling used clothing. My clients are my neighbors. This business has helped me and my family a lot. Now I need to buy more stock, because I have had several requests and want to give my clients better service. I would be very grateful for your help.

Translated fro Spanish by Antonio P, Kiva Volunteer

Yo tengo un pequeño negocio en mi casa de venta de ropa usada. Mis clientes son mis besinos. Este negocio me ayudado mucho y a mi familia tambien. ahora nesecito comprar mas ropa en este mes porque tengo varios encargos y quiero darles un mejor servicio a mi clientela. Me gustaria mucho que me pudieran ayudar.

loans.use: To buy used clothing for resale

loans.name: Jessica

texts.es:
Business Description

Jessica works hard to sell uniforms and books to a school in her community. She started this business 10 years ago with the help of her brother who is the direct of this school. In this business, her husband helps her. These days, her sales have increased since the school's student body has also grown.

Loan Use

She needs the loan to purchase merchandise like casual uniforms, since they are in a period of performing civic duties.

Personal Details

She is 25 years old and has one son and lives in her parents home. Her goal is to make money from her sales to build her own home.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

La Sra. Jessica se dedica a la venta de uniformes y libros en una escuela de su comunidad empezó hace 10 años con la ayuda de su hermano que es el director de dicha escuela. En el negocio le ayuda su esposo hoy en día sus ventas han aumentado ya que la escuela también ha crecido

Uso del Préstamo

Ella necesita invertir en la compra de mas mercadería tales como uniformes casuales ya que estamos en temporada de actividades cívicas.

Información Personal

Ella tiene 25 años y un hijo y vive en casa de los padres y su meta es en un futuro con las ganancias de sus ventas poder construir su casa.

loans.use: To buy more uniforms and other products

loans.name: Kalala

texts.en:
Kalala is a married mother of 53 years of age. She has 6 children and 4 grandchildren. Her husband was a fisherman, and from fishing they managed to pay for her children’s school fees and slowly develop her family home.

Her husband used to fish using spears. He has always wanted to have a fishing boat to make it easier. She heard of the programme through other women of the Centre and she was very excited to join so she could get a loan to buy what her husband wanted. Kalala is hoping that one day she will be able to buy a bigger boat so her husband can catch more per trip.

loans.use: To buy fishing boat

loans.name: Akutwala Ekino Lending Group

texts.en:
Tatoo is the chairperson for the Akutwala Ekino Lending Group in the Kyebando District of Kampala. She is the lady in the far left of the photo. Tatto is 35 years old and married with six children. She has operated her restaurant for two years. One day she hopes to be able to build some rental units. She will use this loan to continue buying foodstuffs for her restaurant. Tatoo serves typical Ugandan dishes such as matooke, cassava, posho, rice, beans, Irish potatoes, chicken and beef.

At Pearl, loans to groups are the most common. Through its long presence in Uganda, Pearl is able to identify villages that would benefit from microfinance loans. They contact village leaders, religious groups, etc. to see if there is a need and desire amongst villagers. If the need exists, they meet with businesses and begin a month or two of weekly meetings, educating business owners about the risks and benefits of such loans. If agreed, a lending group forms with chairperson, secretary and treasurer, voted in by members of the group. Members chose which businesses will qualify for loans and how much each qualified business member will receive as a loan. The added total becomes the group loan.

It is important that this is done by the group members because, as a group, they are all responsible for the repayment of the loan. One would not want a business in the group to default, because it can cost the other members. This type of peer pressure is very effective. Persons in groups create a very strong bond with each other. They are very supportive of each other and members have long histories in groups. Meetings are very business-like and the sense of empowerment is evident. Pearl meets weekly with the groups to answer questions, collect loan repayments and to offer continued education in finance.

loans.use: To purchase more matooke, posho, beans and cassava for her restaurant.

loans.name: Azra

texts.en: My name is Azra A. and I live in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I am married and the mother of seven children, two girls and five boys. I make a living sewing clothes for the people of my neighborhood, and my husband sells old and used shoes in the local market. My husband needs a loan of $175 to buy shoes in bulk for his shop.

loans.use: Buy old and used shoes in bulk

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en: Isatu K. K. is 36 years old and married with 3 children.  She has been running her restaurant business for 6 years and the income is a supplement to the family expenses.  With the previous loans, Isatu was able to purchase the ingredients on wholesale, thus she realized better profits.  Her plan is to expand the business and construct a small shelter for her customers. She is therefore requesting a loan of $350.

loans.use: She would like to expand her restaurant to serve more customers and increase her profits.

loans.name: Nuevo Renecer Group

texts.en:
Rudilani is the coordinator of the Bank of Hope, Nuevo Renacer, which roughly translates to “rebirth” in English. Their Bank of Hope is the first such group to be formed in their community of La Barquita and they are proud to be part of the new relationship between their community and Esperanza International.

Rudilania is a 28 year old woman who lives with her husband. They have one daughter together but due to tough economic circumstances their daughter lives with her grandmother.

Rudilania has asked for this loan to start a new business selling clothing. She plans to make a part of her small house a sales room and will travel around her neighborhood to market her new store. Specifically, she is excited to begin selling new mens' and womens' jeans, as well as blouses and undergarments. She will purchase the clothes from a market in Santo Domingo called Villa Consuelo, an area famous for high-quality, imported clothes at discount prices. Through the training she received from Esperanza, she learned that purchasing clothes at a wholesale discount, or at a small discount, substantially increases her profit margin, and consequently enables her to generate more income.

Her biggest goal is to provide a better life for her daughter and give her what she herself never had growing up. Her personal goal is to continue studying and to graduate from the medical school she has been studying at. Rudilani is being trained in dialysis and blood work, as well as in providing vaccinations. Her biggest challenges revolve around the lack of opportunity to improve her business and to work. For the first time in a year and a half, Esperanza International is giving her the opportunity to return to work and create a stable income for her family.

In her free time, she likes to spend as much time as she can with her daughter, as well as study, read, and go to her local church. Rudilania sincerely thanks everyone who is supporting not just her loan, but also the loans of her group members. She says that without opportunities like these, they are not able to move forward with their lives and live the lives that they know they can. On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza, and the entire Nuevo Renacer Bank of Hope, we thank you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase jeans, blouses and other clothing in bulk

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucia has belonged to the Ccatarisun Communal Bank that means “Lift us” in Quechua, for 2 years. Lucia is single and 28 years old, Lucia together with her sister has a restaurant in a central street of the city of Ayacucho. Furthermore Lucia together with her mother has a grocery store. Lucia needs a loan of 1750 soles, money that she will invest in the purchase of rice, oil, sugar, pumpkin, tomato, and meats. Lucia’s dreams are of supplying her store, entertaining in her home, finishing her studies and to be a professional.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Lucia pertenece al Banco Comunal Ccatarisun que significa “Levantémonos” en quechua, hace 2 años .

Mientras que Lucia es soltera y tiene 28 años, Lucia junto a su hermana tienen un restaurante en una calle céntrica de la ciudad de Ayacucho. Ademas Lucia junto a su mama tiene una tienda de abarrotes.

Lucia necesita un préstamo de 1750 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz, aceite, azúcar, zapallo, tomate, carnes.

Los sueños de Lucia son surtir su negocio, tener un recreo en su casa, terminar sus estudios y ser profesional.

loans.use: Lucia needs a loan of 1750 soles, money that she will invest in the purchase of rice, oil, sugar, pumpkin, tomato, and meats.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth A. is 36 years old. She is married with three children who are currently in school. She also has been taking care of two young siblings at the school since they lost their parents.

She sells baby clothes, diapers, powder, napkins, detergents, feeding bottles as well as plastic chairs. She wants to use the loan to buy more supplies of baby clothes, napkins, diapers, baby oil, detergents and plastic materials to increase her stock to earn more income so she can provide her children with a good education.

She is a member of the group called Faith Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans. .

loans.use: To buy more supplies of baby clothes, napkins, diapers, baby oil, detergents and plastic materials.

loans.name: Miguel Angel's Group

texts.es: Hola mi nombre es Miguel Angel D., tengo 34 años de edad, estoy casado y tengo 3 hermosos hijos que los tengo estudiando en la escuela regional de nuestra ciudad, soy comerciante y tengo 3 años de vivir en esta ciudad y es el mismo tiempo que tengo de dedicarme a este negocio, hasta el momento me va muy bien ya que las personas aqui comen muchas verduras por lo saludables que son, mi clientela es especial ya que me tienen mucho aprecio por la forma en que los trato, tamabien viajo a varias colonias y aldeas para vender mi producto, sin embargo en estos momentos no cuento con capital para surtir mi negocio, tengo que vender mas para poder tener mayores ganancias y asi poder alimentar mi familia, y tambien para poder comprar combustible que este sumamente caro en nuestro pais.

loans.use: compra de repollo, tomates, papas, chile dulce, brocoli, cebollas, limones, patastes,

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 46 years old. She is a married woman with seven children between the ages of 7 and 24. She became a snacks seller in 2006. Every day, she works from 6am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Amina now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Meena's Group

texts.en:
Meena baji is a wife of M. and lives in the city of Arifwala, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 20 years. She is the mother of seven children: six sons and one daughter. Her husband is a wholesaler; he buys fertilizer and corn from the wholesale market and sells them in different cities. Meena baji is a housewife and prefers to do household work. She successfully repaid two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for another loan to buy fertilizer and corn to expand her husband's business on a larger scale.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members. Rashidan baji wants a loan to buy raw sugar to re-sell. Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy fruit to re-sell. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy paint for her paint shop. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy inventory for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and corn to sell retail

loans.name: Margot

texts.es:
Margot es socia del Banco Comunal Futuro hace 2 años y lo que le gusta de su Banco Comunal son las capacitaciones que recibe.

Margot es casada, tiene 27 años, 1 hijo y esta en espera de su segundo hijo, Margot tiene una tienda en una galería cercana al mercado central de la ciudad de Ayacucho, el local es alquilado, Margot vende calzados variados para damas y caballeros, actividad que realiza junto a su esposo hace 3 años, sus productos los adquiere en la ciudad de Lima a donde viaja mensualmente dependiendo de la demanda de sus productos.

Margot necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de calzados de varones. Margot sueña con mejorar su casa, ampliar y hacer crecer su negocio y que su hijo sea profesional.
texts.en:
Margot has been a member of the Futuro Communiry Bank for two years and what she likes about the Community Bank is the training that she receives.

Margot is married, is 27 years old, has one child, and is expected her second child. Margot has a store in a gallery close to the central market in the city of Ayacucho. Her premises are rented. Margot sells varied footwear for women and men. She has pursued this activity with her husband for 3 years. She buys the products in the city of Lima, where she travels monthly depending on the demand for her products.

Margot needs a loan of 3000 soles, which will be invested in the purchase of footwear for men. Margot dreams of improving her home, of expanding and growing her business, and of her son becoming a professional.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Margot needs a loan of 3000 soles, which will be invested in the purchase of shoes for men.

loans.name: Habiba Selemani's Sea Cliff A Group

texts.en:
Habiba S. is 39 years old and married with two children, aged 20 and 14. Habiba owns a general store in Magomeni where she sells items such as sugar, soap, rice, and kangas (traditional Swahili cloths). She opened her store 3 years ago and works daily from 6 a.m. until 10 p.m. She is able to earn a monthly profit of about $167.

This will be Habiba's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the first loan to increase the stock of her shop and has since paid the loan back successfully. She intends to use this new loan for the same purpose.

Habiba will share this loan with her subgroup, Sea Cliff A. The group has 6 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Habiba is sitting second from the left.

loans.use: To increase stock of shop.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of shoes and clothing for a small business.

loans.name: Fidel

texts.fr: Né vers 1973 dans l’arrondissement de KESSOUNOU de la commune de DANGBO, monsieur    H. Fidel est marié et père de 3 enfants dont 1 scolarisé. Il est un cultivateur dans le village de GLAHOUNSA de la vallée de l’Ouémé et est membre du groupement  GH MISSIMAHOU DE GLAHOUNSA. Les habitants de ce village font les travaux champêtres à la décrue du fleuve ouémé. Leurs terres sont riches et les offrent un bon rendement.  Leurs spéculations principales sont la culture du maïs, du piment, des légumes, du gombo, de la tomate et du manioc. Le problème de ces habitants riverains du fleuve est que, en période de crue, ils n’ont plus d’activité et dépensent tout le revenu issu de la campagne écoulée à la consommation. A la décrue ils n’ont plus d’argent pour payer la main d’œuvre indispensable pour emblaver la superficie à eux disponible.  La pratique dans le milieu qui consiste au bradage des récoltes ne les sécurise pas et les runes d’avantage. Cette pratique est la vente à un prix dérisoire de la récolte future a un nantis pour disposer de la somme nécessaire aux travaux champêtres. Fatigués de cette pratique il a sollicité un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour l’exploitation d’environ 1hectares des spéculations susse indiquées.
texts.en:
Born around 1973 in the district of Kessounou in the town of Dangbo, Mr. Fidel H. is married and the father of three children one of whom is enrolled in school. He is a farmer in the village of Glahounsa in the valley of the Ouémé River and is a member of the GH Missimahou Group of Glahounsa.

The inhabitants of this village work their fields after the waters of the river Ouémé have receded. Their land is rich and gives them a good harvest. Their main crops are maize (corn), hot peppers, vegetables, okra, tomatoes, and manioc. The problem for these people who dwell along the river is that, when the river floods, they have no work and spend on food all the money they earned farming last season.

When the waters recede, they have no money left to pay workers who are indispensable to help them cultivate the area available to them. At this point many sell the future rights to their harvest which does not make them any more secure, but only makes things worse. They sell the rights to their future harvest to a wealthier person for a laughable sum so that they have enough money to be able to work their fields. Weary of this system, Fidel H. is requesting a loan of 100,000 F CFA so as to farm about 1 hectare, growing the above-mentioned crops.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: farming 1 hectare in corn and hot peppers

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.en:
Guadalupe is a member of the Legion Village Bank. She is 51 years old and is the widowed mother of three children. 

Guadalupe has a stand in the market where she sells grains, which she buys in regional markets. Guadalupe also buys cheese and animals at these regional markets. She slaughters the animals and sells the meat and cheese from door to door.  

Guadalupe needs a loan of 1050 soles to buy rams.  Guadalupe dreams of building a third floor onto her house and of improving her businesses. 


Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Fellow

Guadalupe es socia del Banco Comunal Legión. 
Guadalupe es viuda, tiene 51 años y 3 hijos, Guadalupe tiene un puesto en el mercado 12 de abril en donde vende cereales, los que son adquiridos de los feriantes. Además Guadalupe viaja a las ferias en donde compra quesos, animales que luego beneficia y vende de casa en casa. 
Guadalupe necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra carneros. 
Guadalupe sueña con construir el tercer piso de su casa, mejorar sus negocios.

loans.use: To buy rams

loans.name: Sokhom

texts.en: Mrs. Sokhom K. is a villager in the Sro Mor village in the Takeo province. She is 40 years old and the mother of five children, three of whom attend the local school while the others are too young to work or study. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice to earn a living. She now faces a problem because her field is infertile.  So she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and to buy pesticides to kill the insects. Her husband, Mr. Nak Sovann, helps her on the plantation. Her husband is shown with her in the picture.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 34 years old and married to Salvador L., Jr. The couple was blessed with three children: Julius Jay -11 years old; Victoria Pearl - 9 years old, both in the elementary level, and the youngest is Jiabeth - 4 years old. The family lives in Barangay (township) Villa Gamiao, a simple village in San Mateo, Isabela.

Betty manages a "rolling store" in their village that offers different types of goods to earn money for their children and for their daily needs. Aside from that, she also sells native cakes and other foods for snacks. From her business, she is able to earn an average weekly income of PHP 1,000 that she budgets for her family and as rolling capital. She is planning to put up a mini-restaurant in their place for added income.

With this, she is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 for the development and improvement of her store. Some of her loan will also be used to repair her bicycle that she uses in her rolling business; it needs repair so she can avoid accidents. According to her, patience and love of the business are essential to every entrepreneur like her in order to succeed.

loans.use: store improvement

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Phạm Thị Hải 49 tuổi, chị là thành viên Quỹ tình thương từ năm 1995. Trước khi tham gia Quỹ tình thương kinh tế gia đình chị rất khó khăn do thu nhập chủ yếu dựa vào chăn nuôi, trồng trọt. Sau khi tham gia Quỹ, nhờ có thêm nguồn vốn chị đã đầu tư mở rộng chăn nuôi  và mua đồ nấu rượu bán. Hiện tại đây cũng là những công việc đem lại nguồn thu  chính cho gia đình  chị với thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Ngoài thời gian phụ giúp vợ trong công việc chăn nuôi, để tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình anh Minh chồng chị còn làm thêm nghề xe ôm cho thu nhập 1.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư vốn mua thêm lợn về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Phạm Thị Hải, 49 years old, has been a member of the TYM Fund since 1995. Before she joined the Fund, the financial situation of her family was very difficult because their income depended solely on raising animals and farming. When she joined the Fund, she used this source of capital to expand her activities raising animals and to buy equipment for brewing wine. Now, these are the main sources of income for her family, providing them with income of 2,000,000 VND (117 USD) per month. Besides helping Hải with the animals, her husband Minh works as a motorbike taxi driver to earn an extra 1,000,000 VND (58 USD) per month for the family. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 15,000,000 VND (875 USD) to buy more pigs to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Rorn

texts.en:
Rorn M. lives in Trang village, in Takeo province.  She is a Bro Hok seller in the local market.  Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand.  She decided to request a loan to buy more Pro Hok to re-sell to earn more income to support her family. 

Her husband, Chan Young, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice.  Rorn is a 45 year old mother of three children who attend the local school.  Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: Buy more Pro Hok to re-sell.

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle S. is a 41-year-old mother of eight. She works very hard to support the needs of her big family. Her husband is a laborer and a farmer who works a small parcel of land. She buys and resells vegetables in "talipapa," a small market in the village that sells all the basics necessities.

Annabelle joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) five years ago to get additional capital for her business. She applied for this loan to support her present business which she wants to sustain. She wants to buy volumes of vegetables during market day of Hamtic, the town proper, to sell in the village for the whole week in order to earn a bigger income. She hopes that she can save money for the education of her children and that she will be able to provide for all the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy vegetables for resale

loans.name: Katia Group

texts.en:
The group name is Katia; it is made of five women who are living in the region of the Bekaa, Lebanon. 

Ayda is a 41-year-old married woman with two children. She has owned livestock for twenty years. She requested a loan of 300 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to increase her livestock. This is the first time that she has requested a loan.
Ayda is special in her work because of her experience. Her clients are people from her region. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. She decided on her business because it is in demand in her region. In the future, she plans on expanding her livestock. 

Katia is a 56-year-old woman. She has been working in agriculture for fifteen years and owns livestock. She requested a loan of 300 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to increase her livestock. This is the first time that she has requested a loan.
Katia is special in her work because she likes what she does. Her clients are people from her region. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulties. In the future, she plans on improving her work. 

Faryha is a 31-year-old married woman with five children. She has been working in agriculture for fifteen years and owns livestock. She requested a loan of 300 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to increase her livestock. This is the first time that she has requested a loan.
Faryha is special in her work because of her experience. Her clients can be anybody from her region. Faryha decided on her business because she likes animals. In the future, she plans on improving her work. 

Almaza is a 28-year-old woman. She has been working in agriculture for six years and owns livestock. She requested a loan of 300 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to increase her livestock. This is the first time that she has requested a loan.
Almaza is special in her work because of her experience. Her clients can be anybody from her region. In the future, she plans on improving her work by expanding her livestock. 

Khayriya is a 51-year-old married woman with seven children. She has been working in agriculture for six years and owns livestock. She requested a loan of 300 U.S. dollars from Al Majmoua in order to increase her livestock. This is the first time that she has requested a loan.
Khayriya is special in her work because of her experience. Her clients can be anybody from her region. She decided on her business because she learned it since she was young. In the future, she plans on improving her work by expanding her livestock.

loans.use: To increase their livestock

loans.name: Sinignessigui Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Sinignessigui  est  constitué de sept femmes monogames  qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et ont en moyenne  2 enfants. Elles habitent à Bougoula hameau, une des communes rurales  de  Sikasso  (3ème région administrative du Mali).
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments alimentaires,  des pagnes wax, du  bois de chauffe et des chaussures. 
Elles sont à leur  troisième  collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de satisfaire le besoin croissant des  clients  et d’accroitre leurs revenus. Tous les prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés. 
Elles comptent acheter avec ce nouveau prêt,  25 paniers de condiments, 40 pièces de pagnes wax, 10 chargements de charrettes en  bois de chauffe et 80 paires de chaussures. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso auprès des grossistes  et dans les villages environnants auprès des producteurs. Les marchandises sont vendues dans les marchés de la ville de  Sikasso, à domicile et de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes  généralement au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 21 000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée dans la nourriture et l’habillement des enfants et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités et le remboursement du prêt.
Les femmes du groupe Sinignessigui ambitionnent  devenir des  grossistes et effectuer des voyages entre le Mali et les pays frontaliers.
texts.en:
The group Sinignessigui is composed of seven monogamous women who average 33 years of age and 2 children each. The women live in the hamlet of Bougoula, a rural community of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They operate diverse businesses, including the sale of condiments, Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), firewood, and shoes. They are on their third collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of satisfying the growing customer demand and increasing their revenues. All of the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. With this new loan, the group members intend to buy 25 baskets of condiments, forty bolts of Wax pagnes, ten cart-loads of firewood, and eighty pairs of shoes. Supplies are gotten at the grand marketplace of Sikasso City from wholesalers and in surrounding villages from producers. The merchandise is sold in cash transactions generally, at the marketplaces of Sikasso City, out of the house, and door-to-door. The customers are composed of women and men. The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 21,000 francs CFA. A portion will be used for feeding and clothing the children, and the other portion will be invested in business and used for making loan payments. Their ambition is to become wholesalers and to make trips between Mali and the bordering countries.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various goods

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es: Carlos tiene 52 años, está casado y es padre de 6 hijos, por quienes viene trabajando arduamente; entre otras cosas, construyó con sus propias manos la casa donde ahora habitan, por lo que su familia aprecia el esfuerzo que diariamente realiza. Hace 30 años viene trabajando como maestro de obras en construcción según los contratos que tiene con las edificaciones de viviendas en su distrito, donde es muy conocido por la eficiente labor que realiza. Esta actividad la aprendió desde muy joven de su padre y él la ha ido perfeccionando con el paso del tiempo. Su labor demanda mucho esfuerzo físico, pues tiene que cargar los diversos materiales de construcción y operar con mucho cuidado cada máquina que utiliza, por lo que la experiencia le ha enseñado a ser muy cuidadoso y prevenido. Para un futuro cercano, Carlos desea  adquirir su propia maquinaria para dejar de pagar los costos del alquiler de éstas. Este es su 9no préstamo con MFP, donde el entusiasmo y cooperación que hay en su grupo han sido determinantes para el crecimiento de su banco comunal. Con los 2000 soles que solicita renovará algunas herramientas que ya están deterioradas por los años de uso y son indispensables para su labor.
texts.en:
52-year old Carlos is married and has six children; he works hard to support his family. Amongst other projects, he built the house where they all live with his own hands. They really appreciate the amount of effort he puts in every day. He started work 30 years ago as a construction foreman building houses on contract in the area where he lives. He is well known for his efficient work. As a young man, he learned this trade from his father and has been perfecting it ever since. The work requires much physical strength because he has to carry various kinds of construction materials, and to operate very carefully each of the machines that he uses. His work has taught him to be very careful and well organized. In the not too distant future, Carlos wants to acquire his own equipment so that he doesn’t have to pay the cost of renting it. This is his ninth loan with Kiva partner MFP. The enthusiasm and cooperation amongst the members of his group have been determining factors in the growth of the community bank. With the 2000 soles loan, Carlos will buy new tools to replace the ones that are worn out from years of use. Without these tools he would not be able to work.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy new construction tools

loans.name: Djeneba

texts.fr:
Djeneba C. est une  célibataire âgée  de 46 ans et mère d’un enfant qui vit  avec ses nièces et son enfant dans le quartier Médine de la ville de Ségou (4ème  région de la république du Mali) 
Contrôleur de douane de formation, elle a commencé le commerce en classe de 8ème (système éducatif Malien) avec la  vente des jus de fruits. En plus des jus de fruits, elle  vend  des sandwiches, des brochettes de viande de bœufs et des boissons gazeuses. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation dans la fabrication de jus et les femmes viennent chez elle pour apprendre les recettes.
Pour faire un cocktail de jus de fruits de 60 000 unités par exemple, elle a besoin de 100 kg d’orange, 20 kg d’ananas et 10 kg de mandarine. Ces fruits pressés à l’aide d’une machine à presser  et le jus obtenu  est mélangé dans 17 kg de sucre avec les arômes et essences, avant d’être mis dans les emballages et mis au frais.
Dans le souci d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour développer   son activité, elle fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son 1er prêt individuel.
Elle compte l’utiliser pour acheter, 4 sacs de sucre, 1 sac de lait et 4 cartons d’aromes pour jus. Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières sur place à Ségou.  Djeneba C. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui lui permettra de payer son loyer,  d’aider sa famille  et de payer son personnel.
Son ambition est d’abord de  se construire une maison.
texts.en:
Djeneba C., age 46, is unmarried and the mother of one child. She lives with her nieces and her child in the Médine neighborhood in the city of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). A trained customs controller, she started her business during 8th grade, selling fruit juice. In addition, she also sells sandwiches, beef brochettes, and soft drinks. Her reputation is this field is very high, and women come to her to learn recipes.

To make a fruit juice cocktail of 60'000 units for instance, she needs 100 kg of orange, 20 kg of pineapple, and 10 kg of mandarine. The fruits are processed with a squeezer, and the resulting juice is mixed with 17 kg of sugar, aromas and essences, before being conditioned and put in the fridge.

Eager to bolster her working capital in order to develop her business, she's seeking her first loan from Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso. She intends to use it to buy 4 sacks of sugar, 1 sack of milk, and 4 packs of juice aroma. She gets her raw materials in Ségou, and sells for cash and on credit, to a clientele comprising both men and women. She hopes to turn a monthly profit of XOF 150'000 (ca US$ 325), to be used to pay the rent, to help her family, and to pay her employees. Her ambition is firstly to build herself a house.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 4 sacks of sugar, 1 sack of milk, and 4 packs of juice aromas

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth B. is from the village of Lopez Jaena. She is twenty-two years old and married with two children, both of whom are infants. To make a living, Janeth owns and operates a business harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Janeth has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $85 a month for these activities.

In 2005, Janeth joined PMPC, one of Kiva's field partners, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Janeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. That loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell. Janeth is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will also be used to purchase more fish to sell. This will be her fourth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by the loan to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Clarivel

texts.en:
Clarivel is a 40-year-old married mother of two children.  Together with her siblings, Clarivel owns and runs a "polleria" which is a restaurant that specializes in roasted chicken.  This is a very popular dish in the city of Pucallpa where Clarivel and her family live. Clarivel herself raises the chickens for serving at the restaurant.    

Clarivel has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for two years and is a member of the communal bank "Mujeres Forjadoras."  Clarivel plans to invest this loan of 3000 soles in fixing up her chicken coops.  Clarivel's goal is to eventually open another polleria.

loans.use: To repair her chicken coops.

loans.name: Emelda

texts.en:
Emelda P. is from the village of Baluarte, Lumbia Cagayan De Oro City. She is 47 years old. Emelda is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Emelda owns and operates a specialized retail business. The main source of income for the business comes from buying green bananas in the local community. Emelda has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Emelda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelda has successfully repaid a previous loan from HSPFI. Emelda is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used as additional business capital.
